title: Gear with setscrew for Wade's extruder

description.text: This is a modified version of Wade's gear that has the advantage that you only need to file a small indentation on the motor shaft rather than two precision flats.

The hole is exactly 5mm so it will come out too small when printed. This is deliberate so that it can be reamed to exactly fit the shaft. If you haven\'t got a reamer you can use a drill.
Insert an M3 nut and a 6mm grub screw.

comments.text: I created a OpenSCAD version of this gear (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4305)http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... it is a derivative of a script by GregFrost and Thingiverse doesn't let you make something a derivative of more than one thing... so this will have to do as indication of my derivative. :)

comments.text: I can't remember specifically what I did to these scans but typically:  I use netfabb to close small holes, cut off "splats" on the ground that are leftover in the scan, and repair other minor mesh issues. title: Surface Mount Component Parts Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have viewed many designs on Thingyverse and downloaded several to print and use. This is my first of, hopefully, many uploads I would like to share. I am starting to build some circuits using surface mount components and needed a place to store and hold the tiny parts, some of which you can barely see with the naked eye. I couldn’t find exactly what I was looking for so I decided to design and make my own.
The holder contains six pockets measuring ¾”W x ¾”L x ½”Deep. I designed the holder to fit two at a time in a clear plastic hinged case measuring 3 9/16”Lx 2 9/16”W x 1 1/8”H. The model number of the case I used is S-6277 from ULINE if you would like to purchase online. The design allows me to store 12 different components in each clear case and view a label that can be applied to each group of pockets with component descriptions. I hope you like my design and can use for some of your projects. Please let me know what you think by sharing pictures if you decide to download and print. Also, feel free to remix.

description.text:
EDIT September the 14th

Uploaded new STL files, as there was an error with the guiding component, characters would have interfered with movements.

Français

Cela faisait déjà bien longtemps que je voulais un guide perçage sur chant, de manière à pouvoir percer exactement au centre et perpendiculairement. Simplement marquer le point n'est pas suffisant, il est rarement facile de tenir la perceuse exactement en place.

En même temps, j'ai démarré une série de vidéos sur Youtube, tutoriel sur Fusion 360. Cet outil m'a semblé être le candidat parfait, composé de plusieurs pièces mais encore relativement simple. Vous pouvez trouver cette série de vidéos ici: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL0qHSH9_1qY6jR5WaFSh301FLFfPCmOF6

Pour assembler les pièces, vous allez avoir besoin de:

  • 6 mini roulements de 4 X 10 x 4
  • 6 Inserts laiton M4 de 6 mm de long
  • 2 Boulons M4 tête ronde, empreinte hexagonale, longueur 10 mm
  • 4 Boulons M4 tête ronde, empreinte hexagonale, longueur 20 mm

Un kit de ces pièces est disponibles dans la boutique de Le Bear CNC: https://www.lebearcnc.com/produit/kit-quincaillerie-gabarit-de-percage/

English

I wanted to have an edge drilling jig since a while, to be able to drill exactly on the center, and perpendicular. Simply check the center is not enough, as it's rarely easy to hold the cordless drill exactly perpendicular.

In the same time, I started a suite of videos on Youtube, Fusion 360 tutorials. This tool seemed to be a perfect candidate, as it is made of differents components, but still simple enough. You can find this playlist here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL0qHSH9_1qY6jR5WaFSh301FLFfPCmOF6
Sorry, this is all in French.

To assemble the parts, you will need:

  • 6 mini bearings 4 x 10 x 4
  • 6 brass inserts M4, length 6 mm
  • 2 M4 Socket Head Screws, length 10 mm
  • 4 M4 Socket Head Screws, length 20 mm

A package with these parts is available in Le Bear CNC Shop: https://www.lebearcnc.com/produit/kit-quincaillerie-gabarit-de-percage/

Brass inserts have to be put in place with a hot soldering iron.
Bearings may need to be inserted with some force.

title: Porter Cable style bushing adapter for Harbor Freight/Task Force Router

description.text:
I wanted to use the Leigh D4 dovetail jig with my Task Force plunge router (Lowe's used to carry this brand and it turns out it is identical to the 1 1/2HP Harbor Freight router Item#67119).

The Leigh dovetail jig required Porter Cable style guide bushings that were costly but I soon found out that Harbor Freight sells an inexpensive set (https://www.harborfreight.com/9-piece-router-template-guide-set-98361.html).

Then I needed to fit the bushings to my router without having to machine a new baseplate so my solution was a drop-in insert using the existing screws that hold the clear vacuum attachment near the center.

If you want to continue using the clear plastic vacuum attachment, you will need to purchase longer screws (M5 x 25mm) at your local hardware store.

Check to see if you have the same router as either of these. It's likely that it's being sold under other names as well:
https://www.lowes.com/pd/Task-Force-Variable-Speed-Plunge-Corded-Router-with-Table/3265503
https://www.harborfreight.com/1-1-2-half-hp-variable-speed-plunge-router-67119.html

The light bar is motion activated (not by the printer) and is dimmable. For the Prusa brackets I angled the light at about 30 degrees but for the CR10 I angled it at about 15 degrees due to the additional height.

description.text:
This is my first practical design - wall-mounted holder for four Oral-B brush heads. The material used is ABS.

There are four versions available (1 to 4 brush heads).

I attached the holder to the clean bathroom tile by using four small squares of double sided foam tape from 3M. I advise not to use cheap tapes unless you do not mind a shattered holder and brushes scattered around your bathroom's floor.

author: DVanditmars

description.text:
This car mount has been designed to work with practically any phone and any case. It only uses 1 screw(3M that came with my makerbot) and 1 suction cup. The entire rest of the process is printed. There is a possibility of using a 2nd screw to completely secure the "Pressure Spinner" and a couple of rubber bumpers for really tall phones.
It holds very solid if printed to the right size and is rock stable. This is probably the closest you can get to a factory mount off your printer.
I would love some derivatives of this, as it took quite a bit of work to get where it is, but I still feel like it could be much improved.

This comes in two scad files(Generic Cross.scad and Secure Suction Cup.scad) which print to several parts. Secure Suction Cup.scad requires Thread_Library.scad which can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8793. It only takes a few steps to customize for your phone, so open up the "Generic Cross.scad" and let's get started.

  • Measure your phone.

  • Fill in the Phone dimension part of the file. If you are printing on a makerbot or reprap you may need to add about 1-2mm to the size. This varies with your machine and how well it prints to scale.
    • 2b. If your phone is taller than your printer can print(Don't forget to try diagonally), you might want to checkout "SuperTallExample.scad" to see how I handled it(This was what was done for the pictures). Basically I used rubber bumpers bought at my hobby store to create pressure on the back of the phone to stabilize it without reaching all the way around. You could probably do it other ways, but this is the way I found that worked.

  • If your phone has a nub or hump on the back, adjust the crook settings. This causes the arm to bend back wherever you specify.

  • If your phone has things in the center of it, such as a camera or power port, edit the length and width hub offsets.

  • Create the STL for your phone.

  • Print both the "Generic Cross.stl" and "Secure Suction Cup.stl" and assemble. On the Secure Suction Cup places the Pressure Spinner on first, then slide the triangle shaped Cross Connector Arm into it's slot. Place the suction cup into the bottom of the Secure Suction Cup unit, it should be a tight fit.

  • You may need to file down any sharp edges on the bottom of the cross before sliding the two arms together(lining up the screw holes).

  • Push the Cross to the Cross Connector Arm, lining up the tab on the Cross with the slot on the Cross Connector Arm and the screw holes. Place screw through the front of the long Cross Arm.

  • You are done, take it to your car, press the suction cup to the window, then screw down the pressure spinner. There is a small T pin that printed off, use that on the left square hole on the spinner when you have it maximum tightness. If the T is too loose for you, just use a screw or something.
    • I feel like I am missing a lot from here, but hopefully it is enough.

comments.text: Could you upload the parts separately? Also do you mind if I make a few design changes? Thanks! Also amazing design.

I increased the size of the case to accommodate a cheap step-up regulator meaning the pack always puts out a pre-defined voltage (I set it to 8.4v).

Servo plug is for charging as my charger requires the discharge as well as balance lead connected. Do not plug the main discharge lead in to a charger as this is connected to the step-up regulator output.

DC Boost Converter: https://www.banggood.com/5X-DC-Boost-Converter-2A-Power-Supply-Module-2V-24V-To-5V-28V-Adjustable-Regulator-Board-p-1181876.html?p=DU271811622582015018

LED indicator board (2S version): https://www.banggood.com/1-5S-Lipo-Battery-Voltage-Display-Indicator-Board-p-1073721.html?p=DU271811622582015018

5.5x2.1 right angle DC jack: https://www.banggood.com/DC-Tip-Power-Plug-Jack-Connector-Dual-5_5-x-2_1mm-Male-Right-Angle-Cord-Cable-p-1161332.html?p=DU271811622582015018

Also requires 4x 20mm M3 bolts, 2s balance lead, standard servo lead, hot glue!

UPDATE:

If you buy the cheap DC boost converters be sure to buy a multipack. The first one I used blew about 10 minutes after assembling. The boost regulator IC burned up. Replaced the module and so far the second has been fine so perhaps just bad luck with the first module.

comments.text: Question: Isn't the indicator board pretty useless with Li-ions? since they can go way lower in voltage than li-pos.
comments.author: Karatektus

comments.text: Yes and no.  You're correct however it provides some indication as to the state.  In my experience once you get down to 1 light you still have around 500-700mah usable capacity left; use a standard balanace lead battery checker for a better indication of voltage once it gets down to 1 light..
comments.author: Karatektus

comments.text: Still going strong. Looks like the first regulator which blew was just bad luck.

description.text: Most coasters suffer from a similar issue: they stick to the bottom of glasses, resulting in them being frustratingly dropped on the ground, spilling their contents along the way. After searching for a solution to this issue, I decided to design my own. These coasters utilize thin points of contact with your drinks to ensure there is no sticking due to surface tension. Not only that, but the deeper recesses allow the coasters to hold more liquid that may drip down the side of your glasses, protecting your table. The coasters also fit into one-another, allowing them to be stacked up without a separate holder.

description.text:
I used a soldering iron Parkside (cheap from Lidl 12 Euro) with adjustable temperature 48Watt.
The second is a soldering iron Lotring 30 Watt (Gamma 5 Euro) to start up the heating the first 15 minutes.
Tube 320 mm length 21,5/16,2 mm diameter.
Hopper Thing 152380.
Use a copper wire and a hose clamp for assembly.
Then isolate.
Temperature test results.

title: Fireballed Pivoting Doors (Before, During and After)

description.text:
This set of doors gives three conditions. First is the normally closed door designed with age, but limited damage. The second is the door being fireballed. The third is the damaged doors after the fireball. A fireball is included that can either be placed in the space between the doors to appear to be fireballed or can be used as an explosion or fireball separately.
The frame has two types. The first has one side that is incorporated with one side openlock connections. The second is a frame without openlock.
The reason I have not incorporated the two sided openlock base into a single piece with the frame is because it would not then be able to be printed without supports.
My recommendation is to print the two sided openlock for this size which is base SB-Open-lock-v3.1 which can be found here,
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833963
Then print the frame and superglue the base.
The doors at the pivots are forced easily into the groves in the frame, but you may need to sand the pivots for each door until it is able to be squeezed fairly easily into the frame pivot holes without being too loose.

title: ImpulseRC Alien PDB Replacement / Blank & Nut Holder

description.text:
I don't need the PDB for my Alien and that PDB weighs in at 11.6g. Removing the PDB entirely isn't really an option as the frame requires it for rigidity.

So I made this and a nut holder. Since it was thinner and I was using steel bolts ... not only is the 1.5mm carbon cut only around 4.42g but I was able to switch to shorter aluminum bolt because it's thinner and ended up saving like 10g on the build.

Also you could use these measurement to design a frame around the Steele OSD PDB ...

Call me crazy but that's a lot of weight to shed!

You can purchase a 1.5mm carbon cut here: https://armattanproductions.com/pages/product_details/10385

UNTESTED carbon cut for press nuts:
https://armattanproductions.com/pages/product_details/11151
https://armattanproductions.com/pages/hardware_details/27/47

WARNING Right now I'm uploading a nut holder that is REALLY REALLY tight. I printed mine in Nylon and it's fine overcoming the snug fit as it's a little flexible. I don't know how other materials would fair. I've uploaded a decent number of things to thingiverse ... many items go completely ignored, so right now I don't plan on redoing to be a little less snug, but if people are interested, just let me know.

This part is a remarque of the HotEnd holder for Smartrap.
I happened to have a JHead with PTFE tube attached to it with a push to fit connector.
The whole assembly did not fit inside the original part from smartrap guys. You should push your JHead inside the middle hole, your Jhead should fit inside.
Then if you want to keep it steady you can screw the little plate so that your jhead wont move. I also created a special Fan holder for the Jhead to be cooled down.
A special location for a SG90 servo motor is also available on the side of the part. I also redesigned the fishline holder mechanism so that you can tighten it with a screw.
There is a special small hole for the fishline to be inserted in it, and a screw and possibly a nut to fix your fishline. Please Enjoy ;) This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/6XOciEJZaTX

comments.text:
Im interested in modding this to include a FSR(Force sensing resistor) with a Jhead. No servo needed, and no switch.
The idea is to take the FSR and sandwich into the jhead mount. My thinking is the upper plate has a hole the size of the jhead, to lock the jhead in the xy location. this flat plate is integrated into the smartrap xend component. a addition plate, that is the actual jhead mount which locks the jhead in the vertical direction, and mounted under the xend jhead component. When preasure is applied, it squeezes the two plates togeather, and thus the fsr feels the preasure. The fsr is connected to a Arduino pro mini, and detects the tap. What do you think? I'm working on the mod myself using you part as a base.

description.text:
An adapter to put in the glass hole in your patio table so smaller beach umbrella can fit in them without wigglin' all about.

title: Handgun with magazine and bullets (Fully functional TOY!!!)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Also on myminifactory: https://www.myminifactory.com/object/model-handgun-fully-functional-toy-with-magazine-and-bullets-52720

=== December 15th === UPDATE: Version 4 - Assembly guide and firing system redesign.

  • Version 3 was a failure so straight to Version 4...
  • UPDATED ASSEMBLY GUIDE... FINALLY!!!!
  • No longer requires core steel rod - plunger now uses side rails to slide
  • Made Plunger Rod a lot stronger and articulated to absorb any flex there may be (to prevent breakage)
  • Various tolerance tweaks.

=== September 11th ===

V2.1 - changed the plunger and bullet loader carriage to stop bullets falling back into the mechanism once loaded - thanks to the guys that reported that issue.
Updated magazine release for tolerances.
Updated Slide for smoother motion and tolerance adjustment.
Updated magazine body to make it latch into the gun easier than before.
Updated magazine base for strength and general fit improvements.

=== September 9th ===

V2 now finished, Magazine and bullets added. Updated parts for the main frame, loader, barrel and grip covers to accommodate smoother firing function and add in the functional magazine catch/release-button.

=======================================================================

This is a fully functional toy gun with magazine and bullets. The gun is simply something I've been wanting to design for some time and finally got the time to do! Load the 3d printed bullets into the magazine and fire away!

The gun will be updated as improvements to the design are made. I don't anticipate much more will change between this version and subsequent versions although I will keep the list updated below. I will also upload a full build and assembly guide that I'm working on, soon.

ENJOY!!!

Black Death Special

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25 - 0.1

Infill:

Variable

comments.text: Hi I made it, fiddled around a while but finally in good working order.  For the magazine you need to put in that t-shaped part and tilt it so it goes to the top, then put in two pins into the tiny holes so the piece rests on them. You can use a rubber band threaded thru the hole on the t-shaped part and have it anchored on both pins so that it pushes that part up to keep the bullets up. Or, my boyfriend bought a fat spring that we superglued in the magazine and we use that to push up that part, making sure it doesn't push the bullets up too hard - it worked best having the spring just long enough so that the first bullet is held up with not much tension on the spring. Anyway, took a lot of tinkering but figured it out, it was fun.

description.text:
This part is the Z motor shaft holder for the Smartrap 3d Printer. It is designed to hold both 5mm motor shaft and 5mm lead screw. I couldn't find it easily alone so i decided to extract it from it's original SmartRap build plate. I attempted to use another kind of Shaft holder but the Z axis was never set properly. this resulted in the Z axis not having a linear movement.
With this part, the motor shaft will be aligned with the 5mm lead screw, and have a linear movement. You will need M3 Bolts in order to fix them together

comments.text: Have you printed these?  Curious as to what you used.  I've got 0.5mm print head, and I had gapping at the two exterior nut corners.  I also has some gaps between the layers around the bolt hols, and the exterior layer.  I had 0.7infil and 0.2mm layers.  I'm wondering if I should have used 1.0 infil it fills pretty strong, but I'm not confident it will hold up once I bolt it all up and tighten it down.

description.text:
I needed a couple bike hooks with larger space to put the tire in. These work on my 27.5" mountain bikes. Mine's a little tight putting it in as the tires are a bit wider than normal, but it still fits. It's designed to be mounted directly on the surface the tire will be resting on. I had to add some wood below to keep the correct angle since I mounted these on a 2x4 attached to the wall.

Included are STLs for both left and right entry....though I realize you can just flip these in your slicer.

I printed in ABS with 5 line walls and 50% fill at .2 resolution. They haven't broken yet.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
(Work in progress)

This is my Version 2 design. Designed from the ground up to survive my learning curve, single/multi hybrid piece frame to avoid stress points and broken arms with motor wires ripped out (a flaw in my previous design). The design in multi-part and ideally printed out of ABS and solvent welded together (that is how I did it), you can use PETG and weld/glue that together.
The plans are for 2205 size motors, ZTW spider 30A escs, Naze32,and with a turnigy 3s 2200mAh lipo powering it all.
The camera and 5.8ghz TX are still somewhat flexible, and as with all my designs the .scad file is included.

Update 4 December 2017:
I am pushing back the completion date in favor of a related (and potentially fun) project. Details coming soon...

title: Dead Dino (aka Mass Graves of Coelophysis)

description.text:
Captured with 123DCatch at the American Museum of Natural History.  Edited and print ready.  
From the AMNH website: "Mass graves of these animals have been found, indicating they may have been victims of a sudden cataclysmic event, such as a flash flood. Bones of young Coelophysis have been found inside the body cavity of the larger animals. This indicates that Coelophysis was cannabalistic and fed on the young of its own species."

A pretty good catch considering is was taken through a glass case in poor conditions: lots of visitors, lots of glare, glass full of fingerprints, limited range of shots.  Sometimes 123D Catch surprises you.  
DeadDino.stl: Print ready  
DeadDinoLow.stl: Print ready, just fewer triangles  
DeadDinoScan.obj: Rough 123DCatch output  
DeadDionCatchData.zip: Photo sets & scene files from 123D Catch

I've designed a 65mm spindle mount to fit a Shapeoko2! I'm using this mount to hold a Chinese water-cooled 65mm AC spindle. You can learn more about this mount by watching the videos I made about it:
  • Demonstration of the basic features of the mounting system.
  • Demonstration of the dust-collection features of the mounting system.
    • The mount solves the following problems:
  • Mount holds the spindle securely on the z-axis
  • Mounted spindle clears the motor mount at the top of the z-axis.
  • Mount fits onto the existing z carrage and does not add undue angular load to the z-axis.
  • Mount is 3D printable and requires only minimal hardware to install. (M5 bolts of varying lengths)
  • Mount is sized correctly to account for ABS shrinkage.
  • Mount holds a laser diode for help with centering.
  • Mount integrates with a 1.25" vacuum hose and provides dust-collection at the bit.
    • UPDATE
    I've added a new dust-foot, called the Dust Boot. It is an alternate version of the dust-collection foot. This version doesn't restrict air-flow as much, but it does obscure more of the cutting head. I think its better at containing chips and fine dust, but you be the judge! For extra-credit, try adding a strip-brush to make the seal even better! Read more about this project here!

Printing
  • These parts are designed for ABS printing. All of my testing for size/shrink has been done with ABS. It may work with PLA, your mileage may vary.
  • Printing with rafts helps keep the build-plate side from being deformed during printing.
  • No supports needed.
  • The DustFoot has two triangular supports built into the design. These should be detached after printing.
    • Assembly
  • Tap the four outside holes in the face of the mount body.
  • Connect the body to the carriage using M5 screws with nuts and washers on the back.
  • Connect the clamp to the body using M5 screws, clamp down the spindle.
  • If attaching the dust-collection sleeve, Tap the four holes on the left-side of the mount body.
    • Optional
  • Insert a 9mm laser into the hole on the bottom of the body, pass the power wire upwards to the top of the mount.
  • CA glue is your friend. Go nuts.

author: Ryan00101010

description.text:
I needed to join a 1/8" stereo mini phone male with a 3/16" mini phone female using a pair of molded cables. In the past I would have butt spliced, soldered, used electrical tape (or heat shrink) and created a large rope-like knot to act as a strain relief.

This shell separates the three conductors and splices and provides strain relief when filled with 5-minute epoxy. The internal walls made it so I didn't need to use heat shrink and my solder joints didn't have to be pretty.

The modeling isn't my best work and the four alignment holes will likely have openings on outside surfaces when printed on most FDM printers. But, a drop of epoxy on each hole and the four mating pins during potting fills the side breakouts and the overall look and function is spot on.

After soldering, dressing the wiring in the three channels and filling it with epoxy I use a small spring loaded clamp to hold it tightly closed while the epoxy cures.

Not my original sculpt!
I had a buddy of mine ask for me to print this for him
https://sketchfab.com/models/8729a148401b4cda8143f61c4c56c3a9#
So I downloaded blender, converted the file and exported it as an STL.
It does successfully print if you have your shell thickness set to at least 3 layers.
Just thought I should share this here in case anyone else wanted to print it, too.
It's really oddly shaped, but I printed it with the 3 bottom most chins touching the build plate, and with a raft and support.
I also slowed my printer down a ton, but feel free to share if you find a way that works better!

title: Foam board bevel tool (or a Pocket Bixler)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Bevel better than Bixler, ok atleast just as good. That man should have been a surgen. Lets face it, sanding a bevel into foam is messy, and if your anything like me, no two hand cut bevels are alike. Even if they come out nice and clean. This nifty little tool will give you a machine like 45deg finish on your bevels every time.

Left hand and Right hand versions available. Make sure you download and print the correct set. "Foamboard Bevel RH-A" and "Foamboard Bevel RH-B" for the right hand version, and "Foamboard Bevel LH-A" with "Foamboard Bevel LH-B" for those lefties out there.

I know there are a few models out there that do the same thing, but I wanted to make my own version to fit my needs. This was a finiky model. Though the filliment I used is old, wich also added a few defects that didnt help (I need to order more). I ended up having to increase the gap between the atachment points several times before it was usable. If you print this and the parts feel excessively lose let me know and I will modify the model when I get some more fillament.

Designed and tested with R.L. Adams foamboard (photos of black board to show the bevel cuts, white works just as well), and Stanley 11-921 all purpose razer blades. I normally like to make sure generic parts will fit, but in this case I am not certain if these blades are differnt in size than other blades. I can't imagine they would be, but the actual dimmensions were not the same as what I found online. If you use other blades please comment and let me know how they fit.

Note: I model knowing the limitations of my 3D printer. Its old and has a few minor quirks. In general its accurate but holes especially tend to print out smaller than they are sized in the model. As such I model holes slightly larger to accommodate this. Test print any part and make sure any attached hardware like wire or skewers fit properly before bulk printing.

description.text:
In my quest to keep improving my filament spool holders, I started with the basic TUSH, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2047554.

I then had added my raised guides (my remix), which keep the spool over the bearing and not drifting to the edge of the plastic and the bearing. I did find that I had one new spool that had so much filament, that the guides preventing the spool from touching the bearings, so I lowered them.

To get more stability, I then took the rails and the notches in the bottom of the bearing holders from the TUSH++ design, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2451368. I modified the rails by extending the ends, so they could accommodate holes for mounting to keep them from moving.

When looking at other TUSH remixes, I saw that some designers were reducing filament use in the design, so I added some holes on the bearing holder sides. You could still eliminate more filament by enlarging the openings, but I was trying to be a little artistic ;-)

NEW UPDATE - Keep your spools from flying off the TUSH!!!
I keep my spools of filament above my printer on a shelf. When a spool gets close to being empty--and very light-- or the filament gets caught under another coil of filament, the extruder on the printer can pull the spool of filament off the TUSH rollers and then it goes flying off the shelf :-(

My latest update is the "spool holder arms". Since the TUSH already has holes on the side, I create two arms that can fit easily into the holes on the TUSH. On the other end of the arms are two tubes where the smaller one will fit inside the other tube. They go through the opposite sides of the spool going through the center opening in the spool. Check it out. It may break the filament if something happens to tangle up the filament, but it's better than the spool flying off the shelf.

UPDATE - Low profile rail for new spools with filament that goes to the edge.
I have started using the low profile guide on the inside under the spool, and the regular guide with the raised edge on the outside of the spool. This give them same control of keeping the spool from jumping sideways off the bearing rails, but allows for spools that have filament to the edge of the spool (see photo).

remixed_from.author: tylerecouture
remixed_from.title: OpenForge Stone Floor with OpenLock or Magnetic Base

description.text:
So I really like the OpenForge tiles created by Devon Jones, but I find that I want to connect them together and really wanted an OpenLOCK compatible tile.

So I am created some (more coming). These are truly OpenLOCK compatible using the "E" and "U" bases at 50.8 mm and 101.6 mm respectively. This makes them just a couple mm wider than OpenForge since each square in OpenForge is only 25 mm. You can still pretty much use these side by side with OF or DF tiles since the difference is within a mm or two.

I also lowered the relief of the flagstones on the tile a small amount when compared to OpenForge (I felt the tile I based it on was too "humpy"). The stones are about 2.5 mm tall, making the entire tile 10 mm tall instead of 11+ mm. This is much closer to the OpenLOCK "cut stone" tile height, and should be a happy medium between the thinner OpenLOCK and thicker OpenForge bases.

10/17/17 - Added 3x3 EA-TRP base tile
09/12/17 - Added OpenLOCK E-TRP and U-TRP bases
09/11/17 - Repaired minor issues with mesh.

title: Finger and bracket mounting for useless box

description.text: Finger and bracket suitable for mounting servo and switch inside any suitable rectangular box to create useless box. Bracket constrains switch and mini servo at correct position for finger. Servo, finger movements and switch can then be controlled by programming an Arduino board.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Supports are needed for bracket only when printing.

Mounting servo and switch to bracket

Mini servo SG90 is positioned in bracket as shown in photo. Toggle switch is mounted without nut underneath through hole in top of bracket as shown.
The bracket holds both in correct relative positions for finger to engage with toggle switch. This allows the main mechanism to operate independently of the box and also allows for desk checking of operation and adjustment of programming code prior to final assembly.
Once switch and servo are mounted onto bracket, it can then be secured inside any suitable box via the nut on toggle switch through a hole cut in top of box. Position hole in box 10 - 15 mm from edge.
Screws supplied with servo secure servo with small screwdriver through the hole provided in side of bracket. Hole is then used for routing wiring from switch.

Mounting finger on horn of servo

Use thick paper/light card slip to wedge horn into slot of finger.
Poor quality/old PLA filament can split. Had no splits under stress using newer PLA filament.
Finger may be glued.

Bracket for servo, switch and useless box

I wanted my students to more easily design and debug their build and coding for an Arduino powered advanced useless box - as well as making troubleshooting easier for me!
Once mounted inside the box there were too many variables and if wiring is incorrect the whole box had to be dismantled each time.
The bracket allows for everything to be first perfected outside the box.
Critical settings for sweep distance of servo to reach finger, while still returning to a level below rim of box can be established, along with code experiments for different moves for the finger.

description.text:
Here you have a simple version of a famous puzzle - the Towers of Hanoi.
The rules for playing are easy. All rings are put on the left or middle stick, the largest at the bottom, like shown at the picture. From now on, your goal is to put them onto the right stick in the same order, but there are some rules for moving the rings: Only one ring (the one at the top of a Tower) can be taken each time and put onto an empty tower or onto another tower, if the ring beyond it is larger.
If you´ve understood the rules and managed finishing the game, I have a new goal for you - finishing in as few moves as possible. If you have "n" rings for playing, the minimum amount of moves can be calculated by the formula <(2^n)-1>. Let´s see if you manage the six ring puzzle with 63 moves!

author: WarHawk8080

description.text:
The single track standards and brackets shelving systems (like Rubbermaid) are convenient and inexpensive compared to the twin-tracks and other adjustable shelving solutions.

The problem is that they are very wobbly until you place a shelf on them. Even then, they tend to sway about. If you use shelves that overhang the front of the brackets, they can tip forward and lift the rear of the shelf. This makes for uncomfortably unstable shelving.

These anchors are designed to fit under the shelf to hold the bracket to the shelf. This prevents the shelf from lifting off of the bracket, and reduces the left-to-right swaying of the brackets.

The Rubbermaid brackets I made these for have about a 3.3 degree taper to them. These anchors account for that to maximize contact with the bracket.

The height of the bracket increases as you move towards the wall, so you require different size anchors depending on where you wish to position it. I have included 18mm, 22mm, 24mm, 26mm, and 28mm height versions of the anchor. This anchor is customizable though, and you can create other heights.

title: Octoson - Octoprint on the Intel Edison - case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a case which accomodates the Intel Edison mini breakout board, on which the optional 12V male jack has been soldered on the bottom.

It has been designed by taking the DXF Intel provides for the board and extruding blocks for the various ports. In addition to proper openings for ports, the case has cutouts for magnets on the bottom so that it can stick on the surface of your choice. It is currently used as an enclosure for Octoson (https://vrubiolo.github.io/octoson/), whose goal is to run Octoprint on an Intel Edison.

This case was printed on a Printrbot Play, after calibrating it for tolerances. The magnets are meant to hold via a press-fit adjustment (I used pliers to insert them in place).

The entire design has been made using FreeCAD, an open source 3D parametric CAD modeler (http://www.freecadweb.org). The FreeCAD source file for the model is included as well.

This is a work in progress. What needs to be done:

  1. Dial in tolerances/dimensions for the vertical tubes so that the case press-fits correctly (or switch to a new design).
  2. Make it less bulky.
  3. More pics with the actual board

This puzzle cube has 3 unique solutions but is still incredibly perplexing. You can scale the .stl in Makerware to the size of your liking. It is 1.5 inches tall by default.

This was an actual school assignment i had to do. The criteria for the assignment was to design a 3 cube by 3 cube by 3 cube cube with:
a) 5 pieces that interlock
b) No individual piece can be a rectangular prism
c) Each piece must be comprised of 4 to 6 individual cubes. I first drew out 30 or so figures on isometric grid paper and chose one that I thought we be the most difficult and unlikely piece to fit in a cube. As I designed each piece of the cube, I made sure that each could fit into at least one more spot on a different part of the cube; this design technique resulted in a very challenging and tricky puzzle cube.

description.text:
This is a template for making celtic or pictish knot patterns. I have attached a completed knot as an example.

The source software is Rhino 5 and I have attached the template file for you to play with. You can get an evaluation copy of Rhino for free for 90 days and the educational licenses are pretty reasonable after that. But you can get a lot done in 90 days.

To use the tool, drag and drop the 2D pattern and the corresponding 3D pattern across onto the grid. It is a bit clunky, but it allows you to visualise your pattern in 2D which is clear while you assemble the 3D knot. At the end I Boolean the 3D components together and export the whole pattern with 0.01mm resolution as a binary STL.

You can scale the complete pattern to you heart's desire to make it deeper or wider or whatever. I use scale 1D.

If you find this useful, I would appreciate a tip.

description.text:
Yesterday I lost my retainer nut for my SUP fin just before training (it fell through the planks on the pier, good luck finding it back). Luckily someone had a spare one, but I immediately was thinking about creating a 3D printed extra. It should be plenty strong for most applications, but use your brain (if you are SUPping jaws, please don't use it and blame me ;) )

I created two models, both for M4 as that is what my fin uses (but I can add more sizes if you want). One model is using a press fit M4 nut as a thread and the other is just a precise fit on the bolt which you can tap into the plastic.

The one using the bolt feels stronger, but I cannot separate the other one with my bare hands, thus I think it should suffice (and it is way easier and cheaper to make).

If you need a special size you can find the OpenSCAD file here: https://gum.co/DiIab

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I used 15% cubic infill and it should be enough, but if you want to err on the safe side use 100%. I used ABS, but I do not think that using PLA should be making any difference.

Nutless design

You can sand it, but why bother?

Just take an M4 bolt and screw it into place.

Nut design

Take a hammer and an M4 nut and hammer the M4 nut into the socket. This should be enough to keep the two parts firmly together.

description.text:
07/09/2017. Utillaje para el cambio de disco de una amoladora radial de marca desconocida. Útil cuando pierdes la llave original. ;p Diseñado en FreeCAD.
La amoladora dispone de 4 taladros distribuidos uniformemente a 90º. La distancia entre taladros opuestos 180º es de 30 mm, siendo los taladros de alrededor de 5.60mm de diámetro, por lo que se han aprovechado las cabezas de diámetro 5.40mm de tornillos de M3.
El diámetro exterior de la herramienta es de 40mm y el interior de 22mm, y la longitud total es de 125mm. Los diámetros de los taladros se han fijado a 3mm, de tal forma que al atornillar se rosca el plástico. Funciona y parece robusta!
Impresa en PLA a 235ºC con capas de 0.25mm. 5 capas exteriores, 4 superior e inferior y 25% de relleno.

2017/09/07. Disc changing tool for radial grinder of unknown brand. Useful if you lost the tool. ;p. Designed with FreeCAD.
The grinder has 4 holes evenly distributed at 90 °. The distance between opposing bores 180 ° is 30 mm, the holes being around 5.60 mm in diameter, so that M3 screws (5.40mm in head diameter) have been used.
The outer diameter of the tool is 40mm the inner is 22mm, and the total length is 125mm. The diameters of the holes have been fixed to 3mm, so that the screw makes the thread in the plastic piece. It works and seems sturdy!!
Printed in PLA at 235ºC with layers of 0.25mm. 5 outer layers, 4 top and bottom layers and 25% infill.

title: IKEA lack printer case spool holder

description.text:
in addition to the lack cabinet I made a spool holder for the Prusa to take up to 4 spools of filament, because the MMU.

The total amount could be up to 4 kg of filament, plus the spools itself and the hangers components.
That's why I recommend an enforced top instead of the cheap lack tabletop.

Then you can screw it under the top and hang on the required filaments.

Use the base sockets, guide a 530mm long aluminum or steel rod with 10mm diameter.
The single hanger has two bearings within, 6000 type, and another short (130-135mm) rod to take the spool.

Zum bestehenden IKEA Lack Kabinett habe ich einen spulenhalter für den Prusa entwickelt, um bis zu 4 Spulen Filament unterzubringen, für das Multi-Material-Upgrade (MMU).

Das Gesamtgewicht könnte bis zu 4 kg Filament betragen, plus die Spulen selbst und die Komponenten der Aufhängung.
Deshalb empfehle ich eine verstärkte Holzplatte statt der billigen, wenig tagfähigen, Tischplatte des IKEA Lack Tischs. Ich hab hier eine Siebdruckplatte von 9mm Stärke zwischen Tischbeinen und Tischplatte eingesetzt. Da kann ich allerhand anhängen, damit der Raum über dem Drucker nicht zu umfangreich verschwendet wird.

Dann kann die gesamte Aufhängung direkt unter die Oberseite geschraubt werden und die benötigten Filamente eingehängt werden.

Verwende die Sockel, führe einen 530mm langen Rundstab aus Aluminium- oder Stahl mit 10mm Durchmesser hindurch. Hab sowohl 12, 10mm als auch 8mm im Obi Baumarkt als 1m-Stab gesehen. Im örtlichen Baumarkt sollte man also was finden können.
Der einzelne Aufhänger hat zwei Kugellager, Typ 6000 (10mm innen, und 26mm außen), und eine andere kurze (130-135mm) Stange, um die Spule zu halten.

60%

description.text:
It is a pair of speakers (70x70x70mm) and a small amplifier (55x50x30mm) to form this speaker system.

The speaker

I used a 2 inch driver unit for the speaker. Round corners at the four sides, the wood was bended in the desired curve. Finally I did the living-hinge right.

The amplifier

I used a ready-made PCB amplifier board with 6W x 2 power output, which already includes a 3.5mm input jack, speaker output and 5V DC input jack. All I need to do is to build a small case for the board.

The speaker system can be used a PC speaker , of which we can power it up through the USB port from the computer.

title: Shoe Lifts - For Shorter Folks or Young Kids at Amusement Parks

description.text:
Not tall enough?  Here are some shoe lifts that you can print out and then put in your shoes.  You'll instantly look taller.  If shoe lifts are good enough for Tom Cruise, they are good enough for Makers.  
Shoe lifts were once popular in the back of men's magazines "Look Taller Instantly".  Now you can print them at will and you will never come up "short" again.  
The default design is shaped to fit in the heel of a man's shoe and give you and extra 1/2 inch or so, but you can scale the design if you wish and get taller or put them in a shoe that is smaller.  
In the photos, you can see my daughter who stands 41 1/2 inches tall.  To a kid, this means she is 1/2 inch too short to ride most of the rides at the carnival or disneyworld.  
Worry no longer, kiddo, with my Makerbot I saved the day.  I printer her out some shoe lifts and now she can bother her brothers with all of the thrill-ride screams that anyone can handle.

I have uploaded the .stl file for two shoe lifts. They fit inside a size 8-11 man's shoe. If you need them smaller, scale them in the x or y direction. The default design provides about 1/2 inch of lift. If you want to go bigger than that, scale them in the z-direction. Since you will be walking on these things, go with 100% fill for durability. Wear socks when using these heal lifts and don't injure yourself. Also, if you do managed to score a really tall woman and need to take off your shoes, you are own your own. It's business time! About me: I'm on a mission to produce a bunch of Maker designs for items that would be embarrassing to buy in a store. This idea, that people want to save embarrassment is not new for me. In 1998 I started a company that sells embarrassing items online and that's been good to me. Here are two websites of mine:
MakerLove.com is where I am uploading all of my fun designs.
PriveCo.com is my company, which is also quite fun. Thanks for taking an interest in my designs. I've got a bunch of 'em.

After printing to get best results and interlayer adhesion, place in oven at 50 degrees for 4 hours to anneal the PC.

description.text:
Introducing ProFab’s new PolyCarbonate fan duct/shroud that increases the active cooling capability by of a print by 30%, therefore enhancing the printing performance and its reliability.This is achieved by using what’s called air multiplying properties – the fan duct maximises the velocity and improves the airflow direction by channeling the air towards a narrow aperture which funnels it closer and more efficiently. The designers incorporated vents along the back surface of the duct thus drawing more air and multiplying the airflow volume.

After over 25 different design iteration and printed prototypes, we finalise our design that strikes a balance between design and performance. This improved Active Cooling Fan Shroud comes standard on the ProFab Mini+ (Upgraded MP Select Mini)

ProFab Mini : https://www.printfab3d.com/product/profab-mini-3d-printer/

title: Tacblade Utility Stanley Blade Folding Knife
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my folding knife design for disposable Stanley style blades.
Its a hybrid between a friction folder and a flipper.
Designed for the UK so no lock, but is very stable in the open or closed position.

100% printable, the bolt best at 0.12mm layer height and all other parts at 0.2mm layer height.
Its been designed to print so easily, no support, no rafts, no brims. Very lightweight but also rugged design.

Update 11/09/2017 v21 New bolt with larger tolerance so its not so tight.
Update 09/09/2017 v20 New inner and outer updated for a more secure blade.
Update 09/09/2017 - All new design v19 incorporates a better fit blade cutout, new construction to allow top case to be printed flat with logo up so nicer logo printing, more stable connection through the knife.
Update 08/09/2017 - added an additional lower case file for loose fit as not all blades are exactly the same size.
Update 07/09/2017 - new stl file for lower inner v18 to take up slack when open, also updated Print Layout to include v18 lower inner.

Disclaimer:
Tacblades will not be liable for any damage or injury as a result from use or misuse of the knife printed from these files. It is the responsibility of the owner to handle the knife with care and its intended use as a tool.
It is the responsibility of the owner to ascertain and obey all applicable local, state, federal and international laws regarding to the printing, possession, and/or use, of products made from these files.

Printer:

Creality CR-10s

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Note the bolt is best printed at 0.12mm layer height.

Post Process

The screw and screw hole can be tight at first,
just screw in a few times, tighter each time to clear the threads.

The tolerances are very tight so take care on cleanup and sanding.
square all edges and inner holes for piviot, any elephants foot from first layer should be removed.

You can lubricate the pivot with oil if you want.

author: nrandal

title: Modular Containers for Tactix Storage Boxes

description.text:
These are modular containers that fit in Tactix brand 12 compartment storage boxes.
The containers can be easily moved between boxes and rearranged to make any combination of storage sizes. They are designed to fit within the standard dividers that come in the Tactix 12 compartment boxes, so you can use any combination of containers and dividers, as required.

The Tactix boxes these tubs fit into are: W200mm x L310mm x H50mm.

Container versions
The Tactix boxes have some extra divider slots that are used in the 18 compartment version. to fit around these slots, there are 2 versions of the smaller containers, one for the middle compartments, and one for the end compartments.
The "end" version of the tubs will fit in any compartment, so if you want the flexibility of being able to put any container in any compartment in the box, just use the "end" versions in all compartments.

Where to find the Tactix Boxes

12 Compartment
The Tactix boxes are sold by Bunnings Warehouse in Australia and New Zealand.
https://www.bunnings.com.au/tactix-12-compartment-organiser-storage-box_p2580706

And are available at Homebase in the UK
https://www.homebase.co.uk/tactix-12-compartment-storage-box_p374211

If you know where these can be purchased in other parts of the world let me know, and I'll add them to the list.

If the you can't get the 12 compartment boxes, these containers should also work for the 18 compartment version, you just won't be able to use all the supplied dividers.

18 Compartment Boxes

Amazon
https://www.amazon.com/Tactix-320006-18-Compartment-Storage-Orange/dp/B007ZZI0AU

Alibaba
https://guide.alibaba.com/shop/tactix-320006-storage-box-18-compartment-l_30472377.html

Murdoch's
http://www.murdochs.com/shop/tactix-18-compartment-storage-box/

title: Soldering station
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a case and a tip holder for a high-quality soldering station. Based on a commercially available soldering tip with built-in temperature sensor this device is the perfect station for soldering even demanding SMT components.

The whole project is described in detail on my website: http://www.oe1cgs.at/smd-loetstation/
(Deutsch)

I printed the individual parts in two colours (black and red) as I think this looks nicer. PLA does the job for me as the station is typically used indoors. However it can be powered by a 12 V battery, so it can be used literally "in the field". In addition to the printed parts, the soldering tip and all the electronics you will need:

Bill of material:
4 self-tapping screws 3x12 mm
4 self-tapping screws 3x6 mm
2 Screws M2.5x20 mm and nuts
Tube (I used stainless steel) 12 mm out diameter and 45 mm long

This tube is glued into the tip holder and protects the tip from accidental contact (or the other way round ;)). The bottom of the tip holder is designed to be filled with water which greatly increases its stability.

Printer:

BQ Hephestos i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed with PLA on a heated bed at 60°C.
In the design of the bottom of the station I had to use some supports for the hole where the power switch goes in. Please cut these parts out with a sharp knife.

description.text:
My first design. Only spent about 15 minutes on this. I used MS 3D builder. I needed to extend the space between the electrical wall box and the hanging phone wall plate for a residence due to some paneling being in the way preventing me from sliding the phone into place. I found a similar product online and I used the dimensions for the height and width but I needed mine to be thicker. I simply made two rectangular guides for the screws to pass through.

I forgot to take a picture of this during the install but it worked well. I'll design another that will match the wall plate dimensions itself for a more finished look.

The dimensions I used were 3.65" H x 2.25" W x .5" D. I printed this on an XYZ da vinci 1.0 AIO using PLA.
